{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3691359,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-27T20:53:18.666Z","cooked":"

I’m crafting a Beginner to Advanced playlist of videos for FRC programming and development.

These are currently unlisted. I might unlist them at some point so enjoy.

I might keep a weekly update of these. I’ll update this post when I add more.

Please note I use IntelliJ for development, but I don’t need the plugin necessary.

These are very no frills. Just me in front of my computer programming and explaining.

Link to Playlist

Please enjoy. Feedback is helpful, but only post your thoughts here. I’ve left the commenting system turned off.

If there is something you’d like me to walk through I might be able to add it to the list.

Link to Repo

Sections are in separate branches.

Added Sections 02, and 03

Section 02 deals with controlling motors.

Section 03 deals with encapsulating potentially reusable behavior into classes.

Please remember this is meant for beginners to advanced.

The advanced material will arrive at some point

Kind of a side note
The sound quality in some of the videos is poor.
And I want to speak for myself here I cannot concentrate when the audio is bad.

If you can, I would recommend fixing that.

The ill titled Section 05 is on the playlist.

I decided to go with a more set and forget approach with command making them runOnce. There is a bit of an issue when disabling that I resolve somewhat. Also Network Tables and intended repetition (foreshadowing).

EDIT:
Section 06 is on its way. I take the IntakeCTRE and IntakeREV and bring out the common components into a base class.

This is not a big deal!!! But in the second video of the playlist (02 New Robot Project) , where you mentioned the IntelliJ FRC Plugin… well, it does allow you to generate an FRC project just like WPILib VSCode. So you don’t necessarily need to install WPILib to create the project

I believe you need to install WPILib for all of the WPILib libraries. I don’t think the plugin provides those

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-08-03T18:26:14.414Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":19.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504700,"topic_slug":"beginner-programming-tutorials-playlist","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":76649,"username":"itshow","name":"Hao Huang","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/itshow/{size}/267639_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/beginner-programming-tutorials-playlist/504700/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3700367,"name":"Hao Huang","username":"itshow","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/itshow/{size}/267639_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-03T19:22:33.225Z","cooked":"

I assume when you’re talking about WPILib libraries, you’re referring to the WPILib extension or the third-party/vendor libraries—whatever people prefer to call them. If that’s the case, you don’t need to have WPILib installed (though it’s definitely convenient) in order to add vendor libraries to your project

Once you’ve created your FRC project, you should have Gradle in the root project directory. And now, you can add a vendor dependency JSON file by executing:

# Mac & Linux
chmod +x gradlew # might need to set the execution flag or it will say permission denied
./gradlew vendordep --url=<url>

# Windows
gradlew vendordep --url=<url>

Remember to provide the right URL for the dependency you’re adding. For example:

REVLib:

https://software-metadata.revrobotics.com/REVLib-2025.json

# I use mac...
./gradlew vendordep --url="https://software-metadata.revrobotics.com/REVLib-2025.json"

After executing the command, the REVLib-2025.json file should appear in your vendordeps directory. If not, check your root project directory because sometimes you may need to manually drag the JSON file into the vendordeps folder.

Once the JSON file is in the right place, you can finally install the dependencies to the project by executing:

# Mac & Linux
./gradlew build

# Windows
gradlew build

Nevertheless, it is 100,000% easier to add dependencies through WPILib VSCode. It has most vendor libraries there, and you can just click a button to install them instead of trying to find all the URLs manually, which can be super duper tedious

At this timestamp, you showed the WPILib Vendor Dependencies sidebar, and it is way easier to manage all the dependencies that way!
